00001 <?php
00002 /** @mainpage QueryPath: Find Your Way
00003  * @image html querypath-200x333.png
00004  * QueryPath is a PHP library for working with XML and HTML. It is a PHP implementation of jQuery's
00005  * traversal and modification libraries.
00006  *
00007  * @section getting_started Getting Started
00008  *
00009  * To being using QueryPath, you will probably want to take a look at these three pieces of 
00010  * documentation:
00011  *  - qp(): The main QueryPath function (like jQuery's $ function.)
00012  *  - htmlqp(): A specialized version of qp() for dealing with poorly formatted HTML.
00013  *  - QueryPath: The QueryPath class, which has all of the main functions.
00014  *
00015  * One substantial difference from jQuery is that QueryPath does not return a new object for 
00016  * each call (for performance reasons). Instead, the same object is mutated from call to call.
00017  * A chain, then, typically performs all methods on the same object.
00018  * When you need multiple objects, QueryPath has a {@link QueryPath::branch()} function that 
00019  * will return a cloned QueryPath object.
00020  *
00021  * QueryPath also has numerous functions that jQuery does not. Some (like QueryPath::top() and 
00022  * QueryPath::dataURL()) are extensions we find useful.
00023  * Most, however, are to either emphasize PHP features (QueryPath::filterPreg()) or adapt to 
00024  * server-side needs (QueryPathEntities::replaceAllEntities()).
00025  *
00026  * @subsection basic_example A Few Basic Examples
00027  *
00028  * Here is a basic example of QueryPath usage:
00029  *
00030  * @code
00031  * require 'QueryPath/QueryPath.php';
00032  * 
00033  * qp('<?xml version="1.0"?><root><foo/></root>', 'foo')->append('<bar>baz</bar>')->writeXML();
00034  * @endcode
00035  *
00036  * The above will create a new document from the XML string, find the <code>foo</code> element, and then 
00037  * append the <code>bar</code> element (complete with its text). Finally, the call to QueryPath::writeXML() will
00038  * print the entire finished XML document to standard out (usually the web browser).
00039  *
00040  * Here's an example using htmlqp():
00041  *
00042  * @code
00043  * require 'QueryPath/QueryPath.php';
00044  * 
00045  * // URL to fetch:
00046  * $url = 'http://technosophos.com';
00047  *
00048  * print qp($url, 'title')->text();
00049  * @endcode
00050  *
00051  * The above will fetch the HTML from the given URL and then find the <code>title</code> tag. It will extract
00052  * the text (QueryPath::text()) from the title and print it.
00053  *
00054  * For more examples, check out the #Examples namespace (start with {@link examples/html.php}). Also, read about the 
00055  * qp() and htmlqp() functions.
00056  *
00057  * @subsection online_sources Online Sources
00058  *
00059  *   - The official QueryPath site http://querypath.org
00060  *   - The latest API docs http://api.querypath.org
00061  *   - IBM DeveloperWorks Intro to QueryPath http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/web/library/os-php-querypath/index.html 
00062  *   - QueryPath articles at TechnoSophos.Com http://technosophos.com/qp/articles
00063  *   - The QueryPath GitHub repository http://github.com/technosophos/querypath
00064  *
00065  * If you find a good online resource, please submit it as an issue in GitHub, and we will 
00066  * most likely add it here.
00067  *
00068  * @subsection more_examples A Larger Example
00069  *
00070  * @include examples/html.php
00071  * 
00072  * @page extensions Using and Writing Extensions
00073  *
00074  * Using an extension is as easy as including it in your code:
00075  * 
00076  * @code
00077  * <?php
00078  * require 'QueryPath/QueryPath.php';
00079  * require 'QueryPath/Extension/QPXML.php';
00080  *
00081  * // Now I have the QPXML methods available:
00082  * qp(QueryPath::HTML_STUB)->comment('This is an HTML comment.');
00083  * ?>
00084  * @endcode
00085  *
00086  * Like jQuery, QueryPath provides a simple mechanism for writing extensions.
00087  *
00088  * Check out QPXSL and QPXML for a few easy-to-read extensions. QPDB provides an example of
00089  * a more complex extension.
00090  *
00091  * QueryPathExtension is the master interface for all extensions.
00092  *
00093  */
00094  
00095 
00096 /** @page CSSReference CSS Selector Reference
00097  * QueryPath provides two query 'languages' that you can use to search through XML and HTML 
00098  * documents. The main query language is an implementation of the CSS3 Selectors specification. This
00099  * is the query language that jQuery and CSS use -- and more recently, FireFox itself supports it
00100  * via its JavaScript API. CSS3 should be familiar to developers and designers who have worked with
00101  * HTML and stylesheets.
00102  *
00103  * QueryPath also allows XPath selectors, which can be executed using QueryPath::xpath(). While 
00104  * fewer functions take XPath expressions, it is noless a powerful tool for querying DOM objects.
00105  *
00106  * @code
00107  * <?php
00108  * qp($xml)->xpath('//foo');
00109  * ?>
00110  * @endcode
00111  * 
00112  * QueryPath provides a full CSS3 selector implementation, including all of the specified operators,
00113  * robost not() and has() support, pseudo-class/elements, and XML namespace support.
00114  *
00115  * Selectors can be passed into a number of QueryPath functions including qp(), htmlqp(), 
00116  * QueryPath::find(), QueryPath::top(), QueryPath::children() and others.
00117  * @code
00118  * <?php
00119  * $qp = qp($html, 'body'); // Find the body
00120  * $another_qp = $qp->branch('p'); // Create another QP object that searches BODY for P tags.
00121  * $qp->find('strong>a'); // Find all of the A elements directly inside of STRONG elements.
00122  * $qp->top('head'); // Start over at the top of the document, and find the HEAD tag.
00123  * ?>
00124  * @endcode
00125  *
00126  * In all of the examples above, CSS selectors are used to locate specific things inside of the 
00127  * document.
00128  *
00129  * @section selector_examples Example Selectors
00130  * Example selectors:
00131  * - <code>p</code>: Select all P elements in a document.
00132  * - <code>strong a</code>: Select any A elements that are inside (children or descendants of) a STRONG 
00133  *    element.
00134  * - <code>strong>a</code>: Select only A elements that are directly beneath STRONG elements.
00135  * - <code>:root>head</code> select HEAD elements that are directly beneath the document root.
00136  * - <code>h1, h2</code>: Select all H1's and H2's.
00137  * - <code>a:link</code>: Select all A tags that have hrefs
00138  * - <code>div.content</code>: Select all DIV elements that have the class=content set.
00139  * - <code>#my-id</code>: Select the element that has id=my-id.
00140  * - <code>p:contains(Hello World)</code>: Select any P elements that have the text Hello World.
00141  * - <code>p:not(.nav)</code>: Select any elements in P that do not have the nav class.
00142  *
00143  * @section pseudo_reference Pseudo-class and pseudo-element selectors
00144  * QueryPath provides an implementation of the CSS3 spec, including the CSS3 pseudo-classes and 
00145  * pseudo-elements defined in the spec. Some of the CSS3 pseudo-classes require a user agent, and
00146  * so cannot be adequately captured on the server side, but all others have been implemented.
00147  *
00148  * Additionally, jQuery has added its own pseudo-classes, and jQuery users have come to expect those
00149  * to work. So for the sake of convenience, we have implemented those as well. These include the 
00150  * form pseudo-classes, along with several others.
00151  *
00152  * Finally, QueryPath has added a couple of useful pseudo-classes, namely :x-root and 
00153  * :contains-exactly.
00154  *
00155  * @subsection pseudoelement_ref Pseudo-Elements
00156  *
00157  * Pseudo-elements are new in CSS3, and are syntactically similar to pseudo-classes. To use a
00158  * pseudo-element in a selector, use the double-colon syntax: <code>::begins</code>. The following pseudo-
00159  * elements are defined in QueryPath:
00160  *
00161  * - first-line: Selects the first line -- everything up to the first LF character (\ n).
00162  * - first-letter: Slects the first letter of the element.
00163  *
00164  * These throw exceptions because they cannot be implemented without a user agent:
00165  * - before
00166  * - after
00167  * - selection
00168  *
00169  * Pseudo-elements should be used with care, as they act like elements, but are not.
00170  *
00171  * @code
00172  * <?php
00173  * $textNode = qp($xml, 'p::first-letter')->get();
00174  * ?>
00175  * @endcode
00176  *
00177  * @subsection pseudoclass_reference Pseudo-Classes
00178  *
00179  * Pseudo-classes are more familiar to CSS and jQuery users. They use a single-colon syntax, and
00180  * are used to narrow the set of selected elements.
00181  *
00182  * The following pseudo-classes are supported:
00183  * - link: Matches anything with the href attribute.
00184  * - root: The root element of the document
00185  * - x-root: The root element that was passed into QueryPath's constructor
00186  * - x-reset: Same as above.
00187  * - even: All even elements in a set. First element is odd.
00188  * - odd: Odd elements in a set. First element is odd.
00189  * - nth-child: Every nth child in a set.
00190  * - nth-last-child: Every nth child in a set, counting from the end.
00191  * - nth-of-type: Every nth tag in a set.
00192  * - nth-last-of-type: Every nth tag in a set, counting from the end.
00193  * - first-child: The first child in a set.
00194  * - last-child: The last child in a set.
00195  * - first-of-type: The first child of the specified tag in a set.
00196  * - last-of-type: The last child of the specified tag in a set.
00197  * - only-child: Matches only if this is the only child in a set.
00198  * - only-of-type: Matches only if it is the only child of the given tag in a set.
00199  * - empty: Selects only empty elements.
00200  * - not: The negation operator, takes a CSS3 selector, e.g. <code>:not(strong>a)</code>.
00201  * - lt: Items in a set whose index is less than the given integer, e.g. <code>lt(3)</code>
00202  * - gt: Items in a set whose index is greater than the given integer, e.g. <code>gt(3)</code>
00203  * - nth: The nth item in a set, e.g. <code>nth(3)</code>
00204  * - eq: The nth item in a set, e.g. <code>eq(3)</code>
00205  * - first: The first item in a set.
00206  * - last: The last item in a set.
00207  * - parent: Matches if the item is a parent of child elements.
00208  * - enabled: Matches (form) items that are enabled
00209  * - disabled: Matches form items that are disabled
00210  * - checked: Matches form items that are checked
00211  * - text: Matches form items that are text fields
00212  * - radio: Matches form items that are radio fields
00213  * - checkbox: Matches form items that are checkboxes.
00214  * - file: Matches form items that are file upload widgets.
00215  * - password: Mathces form items that are password entry boxes.
00216  * - submit: Matches submit buttons
00217  * - image: Matches image buttons
00218  * - reset: Matches reset buttons
00219  * - button: Matches buttons
00220  * - header: Matches header fields (h1-h6)
00221  * - has: Matches any items that have children that match the given selector, e.g. <code>:has(strong>a)</code>
00222  * - contains: Contains *text* that matches. This is a substring match.
00223  * - contains-exactly: Contains *exactly* the given text. This is NOT a substring match.
00224  * 
00225  * These generate errors because they are not implemented:
00226  * - indeterminate
00227  * - lang
00228  *
00229  * These are quietly ignored because they require a user agent to be meaningful.
00230  * - visited
00231  * - hover
00232  * - active
00233  * - focus
00234  * - animated
00235  * - visible
00236  * - hidden
00237  * - target
00238  *
00239  * Examples:
00240  * @code
00241  * <?php
00242  * qp($html, 'form input:text'); // Get all text input elements in a form.
00243  * ?>
00244  * @endcode
00245  * @section xml_namespaces XML Namespaces
00246  * QueryPath also supports the CSS3 namespace selection syntax. <b>This is syntactically different
00247  * than the XML namespace tag format</b>. To select a tag whose namespaced name is foo:bar, the 
00248  * CSS element selector would be <code>foo|bar</code> (note the vertical bar instead of a colon). While 
00249  * QueryPath does its best to resolve namespaces to short names, there is a possibility that a 
00250  * malformed namespace will prevent specific namespace queries.
00251  *
00252  * You can also query across namespaces with <code>*|tagname</code>.
00253  *
00254  * @code
00255  * <?php
00256  * qp($xml, 'atom|entry'); // Find all <atom:entry> elements.
00257  * qp($xml, 'atom|entry > xmedia|video'); // Find all <xmedia:video> elements directly inside <atom:entry> elements.
00258  * qp($xml, '*|entry'); // Find any namespaced tag that has `entry` as the tag name.
00259  * ?>
00260  * @endcode
00261  */
